label: [t'uˁ-me rurčː-ul] taˁħ d-uq-ene!
trs: {‎‎The legs are trembling, jump!}\footnote{Within the contexts from which this example originates the subjects of the {adverbial clause} and the main clause differ. The speaker who was guiding a truck full of people urged them to jump off the car because he had problems controlling it. This means that the full translation is `While/because my legs are trembling, jump!’ Out of context, however, the most natural reading is rather: `While your legs are trembling, jump!’ with a same-subject interpretation.}
